name: Werewolf
description: Wolf-human shapeshifter (Global Culture)

name: Dragon
description: Depicted as fire-breathing and winged (Global Culture)

name: Chimera
description: Hybrid Fire-breathing creature (Greek Mythology)

name: Loch Ness Monster
description: Aquatic monster (Scottish Folklore)

name: Mermaid
description: Human-fish Hybrid (Global Culture)

name: Yeti
description: Ape-like being/entity (Nepalese Folklore)

name: Basilisk
description: Legendary reptile often called the “King of Reptiles” (European Mythology)

name: Sphinx
description: Human-headed lion (Greek Mythology)

name: Medusa
description: Winged female monster who had venomous in place of hair (Greek Mythology)

name: Griffin
description: Tail, legs and body of a lion and wings and head of an eagle (Ancient Egyptian Mythology)

name: Centaur
description: Horse with an upper human body (Greek Mythology)

name: Hippogriff
description: Hind half of horse and front half of an eagle (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Fairy
description: Metaphysical form of spirit (European Folklore)

name: Kappa
description: Demon or Imp (Japanese Folklore)

name: Pegasus
description: Divine winged stallion (Greek Mythology)

name: Ghoul
description: A monster associated with eating flesh in graveyards (Arabian Mythology)

name: Pixie
description: Nature spirits and little people (Cornish Folklore)

name: Cyclops
description: One-Eyed Giants (Greek Mythology)

name: Redcap
description: Murderous goblin (Border Folklore)

name: Manticore
description: Similar to the Sphinx consisting of a human head, lion's body with tail of poisonous spines (Persian Folklore)

name: Typhon
description: Deadly Serpentine Giant (Greek Mythology)

name: Sea Serpent
description: A large type of dragon-snake monster found in the sea (Greek Mythology)

name: Leprechaun
description: Fairies depicted as little men (Irish Folklore)

name: Fenrir
description: Gigantic monstrous wolf (Norse Mythology)

name: Hippocampus
description: Lower body of a fish and upper body of a horse (Etruscan Mythology)

name: Cipactli
description: Sea monster associated with being part frog, part fish and part crocodilian (Aztec Mythology)

name: Imp
description: Similar to goblin or fairy (European Folklore)

name: Minotaur
description: Creature with Human body and Bull’s head (Greek Mythology)

name: Hydra
description: Serpentine water Monster (Roman Mythology/Greek Mythology)

name: Fomorians
description: Monstrous and hostile beings (Irish Mythology)

name: Charybdis
description: Deadly Sea Monster (Greek Mythology)

name: Behemoth
description: Massive beast, believed to be like a hybrid of dinosaur or crocodile (Ancient Jewish)

name: Cerberus
description: Three-headed dog referred to as “Hound of Hades” associated with guarding the gates of the Underworld. (Greek Mythology)

name: Echidna
description: Monster that was half-snake and half woman referred to as the “mother of Monsters” (Greek Mythology)

name: Adlet
description: Creature with upper human body and lower body of a canine (Inuit Mythology)

name: Cacus
description: Fire-Breathing Giant (Roman Mythology)

name: Hecatoncheires
description: Three Ferocious giants with incredible strength (Greek Mythology)

name: Geryon
description: Monster with three human-like heads (Greek Mythology)

name: Scorpion Man
description: Creature with body of scorpion and arms, torso and head of human (Akkadian Mythology)

name: Fachan
description: Ferocious Giant with Half a body (Scottish-Irish Mythology)

name: Ogre
description: Predatory grotesque hominid monster (European Mythology/Folklore)

name: Humbaba
description: Lion-Faced Giant (Ancient Mesopotamian Mythology)

name: Scylla
description: Monster that lived by the water (Greek Mythology)

name: Hadhayosh
description: Gigantic land Creature (Persian Mythology)

name: Kee-wakw
description: Cannibalistic Giant half-human and half-animal (Abenaki Mythology)

name: Abaia
description: A magical eel (Melanesian Mythology)

name: Calygreyhound
description: Creature with torso of antelope, head of a wild cat and claws on an eagle (Medieval Heraldry)

name: Phoenix
description: A mythical bird with long life (Greek Mythology)

name: Tarasque
description: Fearsome Dragon-like hybrid (French Mythology)

name: Cockatrice
description: Two-legged serpent like dragon creature with head of a rooster (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Harpy
description: Half-bird and half human associated with storm winds (Greek Mythology)

name: Makara
description: Sea Creature often depicted as a terrestrial animal (Hindu Mythology)

name: Ammit
description: Human devourer with a body believed to be part hippopotamus, crocodile, and lion (Egyptian Mythology)

name: Garuda
description: Human-eagle hybrid known to be a protector (Hindu/Jain/Buddhist Mythology)

name: Winged Lion
description: Mythical beast lion with bird-like wings (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Leviathan
description: Huge Sea Monster (Jewish Mythology)

name: Wyvern
description: A creature with reptilian body and dragon’s wings and head (European Heraldry)

name: Namazu
description: Giant Catfish known to cause earthquakes (Japanese Mythology)

name: Yale/Centicore
description: Four-legged beast creature with boar-like tusks, large horns and resembling a goat-antelope (European Mythology)

name: Questing Beast
description: Serpent-leopard-lion-hart hybrid (Arthurian legend)

name: Elf
description: Supernatural beings with magical powers (Germanic Mythology/Folklore)

name: Mares of Diomedes
description: Quartet of flesh-eating/Man-eating horses (Greek Mythology)

name: Serpopard
description: Mythical animal with body of a leopard and neck of a snake (Egyptian Mythology)

name: Antero Vipunen
description: A giant known to possess knowledge and spells (Finish Mythology)

name: Indus Worm
description: Gigantic white carnivorous worm (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Ahuizotl
description: Dog-like creature (Aztec Mythology)

name: Psoglav
description: Dog-headed monster with human body and horse legs (Serbian Mythology)

name: Aspidochelone
description: Giant Sea Monster with spines on back (Medieval folklore)

name: Sirin
description: Creature with Body of a bird and chest and head of a woman (Russian Mythology)

name: Cynocephaly
description: Jackal-headed humanoid (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Myrmecoleon
description: Ant-Lion hybrid (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Argus Panoptes
description: Multi-eyed monster (Greek Mythology)

name: Ekek
description: Bird-like flesh-eating creature (Philippine Mythology)

name: Oozlum Bird
description: Mythical bird known to fly backward (Australian Folklore)

name: Hellhound
description: Underworld dog with super-strength and agility (Global Culture)

name: Monocerus
description: Horse with tail of a boar, feet of elephant, and head of stag with a single horn (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Water Leper
description: Gigantic frog with a tail similar to lizard and bat wings in place of forelegs (Welsh Mythology/Folklore)

name: Ophiotaurus
description: Serpent-Bull hybrid (Greek Mythology)

name: Unktehila
description: Reptilian monster or Serpentoid creature (Lakota Mythology)

name: Capacun
description: Monstrous humanoid associated with evil (Romanian Mythology/Folklore)

name: Mapinguari
description: Ape-like giant sloth (Brazilian Mythology/South American Folklore)

name: Yali
description: Lion-like creature (Hindu Mythology)

name: Fish-Man
description: Amphibian Human-looking Cryptid (Cantabrian Mythology)

name: Asakku
description: Monsters and evil spirits known to kill humans (Babylonian Mythology)

name: Sleipnir
description: Eight-legged Horse believed to be ridden by Odin (Norse Mythology)

name: A-senee-ki-wakw
description: Stone giant race (Abenaki Mythology)

name: Ushi-oni
description: Bull-headed monster with a horn (Japanese Mythology)

name: Longma
description: Winged Horse that had scales of a dragon (Chinese Mythology)

name: Nguruvilu
description: Fox-like snake found by water beds. (Mapuche Mythology/Folklore)

name: Lou Carcolh
description: Hybrid of Snake-Mollusk (French Mythology/Folklore)

name: Yacuruna
description: Mythical people with head and feet backward believed to live in underwater colonies. (indigenous Amazonian Mythology)

name: Bashee
description: Giant snake known to eat elephants (Chinese Mythology)

name: Teju Jagua
description: Lizard-dog hybrid with seven dog heads (Guarani Mythology)

name: Indrik
description: One-horned gigantic bull with deer legs and head of a horse vaguely resembling a rhinoceros (Russian Mythology/Folklore)

name: Onocentaur
description: Human-Donkey Hybrid (Medieval Bestiaries)

name: Simargl
description: Winged dog or lion (Slavic Mythology)

name: Erchitu
description: Ox-humanoid (Sardinian Mythology)

name: Huay Chay
description: Half-man, half beast creature (Mayan Mythology)

name: Laestrygonians
description: Man-eating giants (Greek Mythology)

name: Mboi Tui
description: Hybrid serpent-peacock monster (Guarani Mythology)
